Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2007 03:45PM Chrysalis wrote: Hi Diane, I'm so sorry that you and your husband are going through this.  This is so hard on everyone.  When I was first dx'ed, my husband took on a lot more around the house, including the bulk of caring for our two girls who were 4 and 7 at the time.  He is normally the most even-tempered, good natured person in the world, but the stress took a huge toll on him over the years.  It took us five years to finally work through the issues and get him to a place where he could deal with the reality of our situation. He also started on Lexipro, which has been a godsend.  I can't speak to the Zoloft withdrawal (although my daughter was on it and when she was titrating down to go on a different SSRI, she didn't really have a problem), but maybe it's worth another try if a good alternative is determined. I think it's great that your husband reached out to you to confide his difficulties.  That's a huge first step.  I don't know if he'd consider any counseling - does your treatment center have a social worker or someone who is accustomed to dealing with cancer issues?  I know ours treats patients and their families for free.  Maybe that's an option. Just when things started getting better for us, I was hit with bone mets.  It's been a year and a half, and I was mostly worried that my husband would come unwound again.  But now we know what the signs are, and we just keep talking.  When he's down, it kind of gives me strength to be there for him, and vice versa. I wish I could give you the magic solution.  It sounds like the two of your have an awesome commitment, and if you have that, you can weather this together.  I'll be praying for both of you and sending positive energy your way. Renee
